quest_title: Which one of the following pairs of gases contains the same number of molecules ?
explanation_txt:
16g \(O_2\) has no. of moles = 16/32 =1/2

14g \(N_2\) has no. of moles = 14/28 =1/2

No. of moles are same, so no. of molecules are also same.
question_plain_title: Which one of the following pairs of gases contains the same number of molecules ?
explanation_plain_text:
16g has no. of moles = 16/32 =1/2

14g has no. of moles = 14/28 =1/2

No. of moles are same, so no. of molecules are also same.
ans1_plain_text: 16g of and 14 g of
ans2_plain_text: 8g of and 22g of
ans3_plain_text: 28g of and 22 g of
ans4_plain_text: 32 g of and 32 g of

quest_title: Electrolytic conduction differs from metallic conduction. In case of electrolytic conduction
ans1_txt: The resistance increases with increasing temp.
ans2_txt: The resistance decreases with increasing temp.
ans3_txt: The flow of current does not  generate heat
ans4_txt: The resistance is independent of the length of the conductor.
explanation_txt: Increase in temperature increases the ionization rate.
question_plain_title: Electrolytic conduction differs from metallic conduction. In case of electrolytic conduction
explanation_plain_text: Increase in temperature increases the ionization rate.
ans1_plain_text: The resistance increases with increasing temp.
ans2_plain_text: The resistance decreases with increasing temp.
ans3_plain_text: The flow of current does not  generate heat
ans4_plain_text: The resistance is independent of the length of the conductor.

explanation_txt:
Let \(|a|=1\) and \(|b|=1\)

Also \(|a+b|^{2} =1^{2} \Rightarrow 1+1+2\cos \theta =1\)\(\Rightarrow \theta =120{}^\circ \)

\[{\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \, \, \, |a-b|^{2} =1+1-2\cos \theta =3\Rightarrow \, |a-b|\, =\sqrt{3} .\]

quest_title: A skater rotating at 20 revolutions per minutes with both her arms outstretched. When moment of inertia is 4kgm\({}^{2}\) . If she pulls her arms moment of inertia decreases to half of original value. The change in rotational KE is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{aligned} \text { Initial } \mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{rot}} &=1 / 2 \mathrm{I} \omega_{1}^{2} \\ &=1 / 2 \mathrm{I}(2 \pi \mathrm{f})^{2} \end{aligned}\)

Now,

\(I \omega_{1}=I / 2 \omega_{2}\)
\(\therefore \omega_{2}=2 \omega_{1}\)

Final \(\mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{rot}}=\mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{rot}_{2}}-\mathrm{K} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{rot}_{1}}\)

quest_title: Wave equations of two particles are given by \(y _ { 1 } = a \sin ( \omega t - k x ) , y _ { 2 } = a \sin ( k x + \omega t ) ,\) then
explanation_txt:
Both waves are moving opposite to each other as the \(kx\) term inside sine function is positive for one and negative for the other.

Negative sign in \(kx\) indicates that region in the -ve X-axis have higher phase angle value than region in +ve X-axis. This suggests that the first wave is travelling in positive X-axis.

Positive sign in \(kx\) indicates that region in the +ve X-axis have higher phase angle value than region in -ve X-axis. This suggests that the second wave is travelling in negative X-axis.
question_plain_title: Wave equations of two particles are given by then
explanation_plain_text:
Both waves are moving opposite to each other as the term inside sine function is positive for one and negative for the other.

Negative sign in indicates that region in the -ve X-axis have higher phase angle value than region in +ve X-axis. This suggests that the first wave is travelling in positive X-axis.

Positive sign in indicates that region in the +ve X-axis have higher phase angle value than region in -ve X-axis. This suggests that the second wave is travelling in negative X-axis.

quest_title: A moving coil meter has a rectangular coil of 100 turns and dimension of 5 cm by 2 cm situated in a radial field of 0.5 \(\text{T}\). The coil is suspended by a torsion wire which has torsional constant 5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-7}\) Newton per degree. Calculate deflection of the coil when a current 24 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-6}\) A is passed into it.
explanation_txt:
In moving coil galvanometer, the relation between current and deflection of a coil is given by
\(I=\cfrac{C}{N A B} \theta\)
\(\theta=\cfrac{24 \times 10^{-6} \times 100 \times 10 \times 10^{-4} \times 0.5}{5 \times 10^{-7}}\)
\(\theta=2.4^{\circ} \)

quest_title: Two coils are made of copper wires of same length. In the first coil the numbers of turn is 3\(\text{n}\) and radius is `\(\text{r}\)'. In the second coil number of turns is \(\text{n}\) and radius is 3\(\text{r}\). The ratio of self inductances of the coils will be
explanation_txt:
Self inductance of the coil is
\(L=\cfrac{\mu_{0} \pi N^{2} R}{2}\)
i.e. \(L \propto N^{2} R \)
\(\therefore \cfrac{L_{1}}{L_{2}}=\left(\cfrac{N_{1}}{N_{2}}\right)^{2} \times\left(\cfrac{r_{1}}{r_{2}}\right)=\left(\cfrac{3 n}{n}\right)^{2} \times\left(\cfrac{r}{3 r}\right)=3: 1 \)

quest_title: If \(z _ { 1 } \cdot z _ { 2 } \dots \ldots . . . z _ { n } = z\) then \(\arg z _ { 1 } + \arg z _ { 2 } + \ldots + \arg z _ { n }\) and \(\arg z\) differ by a
explanation_txt:
Let \( z_k = r_k e^ { i \theta_k} \)

So, \( z = z_1 . z_2 . z_3 . \dots z_n = \left( r_1 . r_2 . r_3. \dots r_n\right) e^{i \left( \theta_1+\theta_2 + \theta_3 + \dots \theta_n \right)} \)

Let, \( \alpha = \theta_1 + \theta_2 + \dots \theta_n, R = r_1.r_2.\dots r_n \)

So, \( z = R( \cos \alpha + i \sin \alpha )\)

Since, argument of \(z\) is between \( -\pi \) and \( \pi \), the argument will differ by \( n\pi \) from \( \alpha \)

quest_title: Which of the \(C - C\) bond is strongest ?
ans1_txt: Formed by \(s p ^ { 3 } - s p ^ { 3 }\) hybridised carbon atoms (as in alkanes)
ans2_txt: Formed by \(s p ^ { 2 } - s p ^ { 2 }\) hybridised carbon atoms (as in alkenes)
ans3_txt: Formed by \(s p - s p\) hybridised carbon atoms (as in alkynes)
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { s p - s p > s p ^ { 2 } - s p ^ { 2 } > s p ^ { 3 } - s p ^ { 3 } } \\ { \text { Order of bond strength } } \end{array}\)

ans2_plain_text: Formed by hybridised carbon atoms (as in alkenes)
ans3_plain_text: Formed by hybridised carbon atoms (as in alkynes)

quest_title: \(\tan \left(\cfrac{\pi}{4}-\tan ^{-1} \cfrac{2}{3}\right)=\)
In \(\Delta ABC \) if \(\angle A \) is acute and, \(a\) is geometric mean of \(b \) and \(c \), then :
explanation_txt:
\( \cos A = \cfrac{b^2 + c^2-a^2}{2bc} \)

Since, \( a = \sqrt{bc} \) we have,

\( \cos A = \cfrac{b^2 + c^2}{2a^2} - \cfrac{1}{2} \)

Since \(A\) is acute, \( \cos A < 1 \)

Or, \( \cfrac{b^2 + c^2}{2a^2} - \cfrac{1}{2} < 1 \\ \cfrac{b^2 + c^2}{2a^2} < \cfrac{3}{2} \)

Simplifying,

\( 3a^2 > b^2 + c^2 \)

quest_title: A boggy of uniformly moving train is suddenly detached from train and stops after covering some distance. The distance covered by the boggy and distance covered by the train in the same time has relation
explanation_txt:
Let 'a' be the retardation of boggy then distance covered by it be S. If u is the initial velocity of boggy after detaching from train (i.e. uniform speed of train).

\(v ^ { 2 } = u ^ { 2 } + 2 a s \Rightarrow 0 = u ^ { 2 } - 2 a s \Rightarrow s _ { b } = \cfrac { u ^ { 2 } } { 2 a }\)

Time taken by boggy to stop,

\(v = u + a t \Rightarrow 0 = u - a t \Rightarrow t = \cfrac { u } { a }\)

In this time t distance travelled by train \(= s _ { t } = u t = \cfrac { u ^ { 2 } } { a }\)

Hence, ratio is given as \(\cfrac { s _ { b } } { s _ { t } } = \cfrac { 1 } { 2 }\)

quest_title: A body of mass 4kg is moving round in a vertical circle of radius 2m with a velocity 6m/s. The maximum tension in the string is.
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{T}_{\max }=\cfrac{m v^{2}}{r}+\mathrm{mg}\)

\(\qquad=\cfrac{4 \times 6^{2}}{2}+4 \times 10=112 \mathrm{N}\)

quest_title: Which of the following statements is true
ans1_txt: Both kinetic energy and momentum are conserved in elastic as well as inelastic collisions
ans2_txt: Total kinetic energy is not conserved but momentum is conserved in inelastic collisions
ans3_txt: Total kinetic energy is not conserved but momentum is conserved in inelastic collisions
ans4_txt: Total kinetic energy is conserved in elastic collisions but momentum is not conserved in elastic collisions

ans2_plain_text: Total kinetic energy is not conserved but momentum is conserved in inelastic collisions
ans3_plain_text: Total kinetic energy is not conserved but momentum is conserved in inelastic collisions
ans4_plain_text: Total kinetic energy is conserved in elastic collisions but momentum is not conserved in elastic collisions

A capillary tube of diameter 0.04cm is held vertically with its lower end below the surface of water. The height to which water rise in tube is

(Surface tension of water = 7.2 × 10-2N/m)

quest_title: On heating a liquid of coefficient of cubical expansion \(\gamma\) in a container having coefficient of linear expansion \(\gamma /3\), the level of liquid in the container will
explanation_txt:
Coefficient of cubical expansion of vessel \(3\times \alpha=\gamma\) (Given \(\alpha=\gamma /3\))

As coefficient of cubical expansion of liquid equals coefficient of cubical expansion of vessel, the level of liquid will not change on heating.

explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: In a laboratory four convex lenses \(L_{1} ,\, L_{2} ,\, L_{3} \) and \(L_{4} \) of focal lengths 2, 4, 6 and 8 \(\textit{cm}\) respectively are available. Two of these lenses form a telescope of length 10 \(\textit{cm}\) and magnifying power 4. The objective and eye lenses are
explanation_txt:
To make telescope of higher magnifying power, \(f_{o} \) should be large and \(f_{e} \) should be least.

\(M=\cfrac{f_{o}}{f_{e}}=4\)

The only combination that makes \(M=4\) is \(f_{o}=8 \, cm\) and \(f_{e} = 2 \, cm\)

quest_title: In which of the following is O.S. of sulphur +2.5?
explanation_txt:
Sum of ON of each element must be equal to the residual charge

\( (\overset{+6}S\,\overset{-8}{O}_4)^{--}\)

\( (\overset{+4}S\,\overset{-6}{O}_3)^{--}\)

\( (\overset{+4}S_2\,\overset{-6}{O}_3)^{--}\) 

\( (\overset{+10}S_4\,\overset{-12}{O}_6)^{--}\) ON per atom = 10/4 = 2.5
question_plain_title: In which of the following is O.S. of sulphur +2.5?
explanation_plain_text:
Sum of ON of each element must be equal to the residual charge

 

ON per atom = 10/4 = 2.5

quest_title: A small convex mirror is placed at 60cm from pole of larger concave mirror of radius of curvature 200cm. The position of concave mirror is so that real image of distant object is formed at pole of concave mirror. The radius of curvature of convex mirror
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)

\(\quad\)For concave mirror

\(\quad\)f = \( \cfrac{r}{2} \) = 100cm

\(\quad\)For convex mirror

\(\quad\)u = -(100 - 60) = -40cm

\(\quad\)\(v\) = 60cm

\(\quad\)f = \( \cfrac{uv}{u + v} = \cfrac{\left(-40\right)\times 60}{-40 + 60} \) = -120cm

\(\quad\)R = 2f = 240cm

quest_title: A projector gives a magnification of 10. If it projects a slide of dimensions 3cm \(\times\) 2cm on a screen. The area of image on the screen will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{m}=\cfrac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{\mathrm{O}_{1}}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{I}_{1}=10 \times 3=30 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\mathrm{m}=\cfrac{\mathrm{I}_{2}}{\mathrm{O}_{2}}\)
or, \(\mathrm{I}_{2}=10 \times 2=20 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{I}_{1} \times \mathrm{I}_{2}=600 \mathrm{cm}^{2}\)

quest_title: A cell of emf \({E}\) is connected across a resistance \({r}\). The potential difference between the terminals of the cell is found to be \({V}\). The internal resistance of the cell must be
explanation_txt:
\(V=E-I r^{\prime}\)

Or, \(V=E-\cfrac{E}{r^{\prime}+r} r^{\prime}\)
Or, \(E \cdot \cfrac{r^{\prime}}{r+r^{\prime}}=E-V\)
Or, \(Er'=(E-V)(r+r')\)
Or, \(E r^{\prime}=E r+E r^{\prime}-V r-V r^{\prime}\)
Or, \(V r^{\prime}=E r-V r\)
\(\therefore r^{\prime}=\cfrac{(E-V) r}{V}\)
